text: Tap at Neighborhood in San Diego. Murky copper/orange pour with a white head. Earthy and bitter, slightly sweet. Good.
Poured from a Crowler into a tulip glass. Hazy amber in color, with dirty off white head. Sweet malty nose, bits of caramel, roasty malt. Taste is a bit on the sweet side, with a sharp bitter finish.
(tap) clear, bright orange amber colour with a small beige head; aroma of jam, orange marmalade, then hint of roast and smokiness; balanced flavour with a long, medium bitter finish
2014 - burnt caramel and toffee nose and flavor, with very light dark fruits. Pretty unassuming, but nice.
Bottle pour. Cloudy dark copper amber with a large creamy tan head. Aroma is nuts, toast, and spices. Medium creamy body. Roasted nuts, toffee, spices, with a very light bitter aftertaste.

Pours deep copper with substantial white head. Lacking aroma....flavor comes malty and slightly astringent. Not surenifnoff flavor or just the malts. Not sweet at all. Hoping it is fresh not sure thenissue but not great.
Reddish brown. Malty booze with some spices and vanilla. Rich malt body, toffee, cinnamon, nutmeg. Decent.
A wintery Scottish that is splendid. Definitely getting all the Scottish notes, with a bias towards malts considering its winter heritage. Recommended.
Bottle@ trailer. Bright bronze color with ivory head. Toast, nutty, dark bread, earthy aromas. Smooth medium mouthfeel. Nice toasty, nutty, earthy hop flavors with lightly bitter finish---tasty good.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 11, 2014 12oz bottle. Brown and Tan mix. Nothing stands out from the nose, just malts and hop mix. Roast and earthy flavors, ash, very dry in the finish. Not impressed.  It lacks needed sweetness.
A roasted chestnut, a crisp winter night, Uncle Walt looking intently through the window.

12 oz bottle from Total Wine & More - Gilbert, AZ. Amber and clear appearance with a lacy white head. Aroma of dark malts, spices, light caramel, cinnamon and allspice. Similar flavor, adding a mild to medium hop bitterness. OK.

12oz bottle pours with a nearly clear amber sort of copper body that supports a thin tan head. The aroma offers up roasted malts, toasted bread, some spicy notes and mild sweet dark fruity esters. The taste starts with malts, roasted malts, big roasty nuttiness and then some modest spiciness. Wow. This has lots of nuttiness going on, its pretty nice.
A little lean but this is well crafted. Dry roast, small doses of spice and plenty of fizz (for the style). Great lift of milk chocolate on the nose. A light touch for the style.

Light retention and good lacing. Smells of caramel, roasted malts, nutmeg and spices. Tastes of toasted malt, caramel, nuts and dark fruit. Bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Malty and sweet aromas. Pours slightly cloudy orange with a tan head. Sweet caramel flavors, leaving a sugary aftertaste
Draft: darker orange color, decent lace/retention. Aroma is caramel, chocolate, darker fruit, nut. Medium bodied, lightly sweet, quite drinkable. Pretty nice.

Bottle; poured a clear orange/amber type color with a khaki colored head. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, earth, and fruit. A nice blended flavor; roasted, caramel, nutty with a good dose of hops in the finish. Touch of sweetness and more earth in the finish.

In all fairness I have heard this beer is usually good. I had a 12 oz. bottle from an overpriced 4 pack and it was bad. I mean face puckering bad. I am a home brewer and know that bottles do not do justice to any brew so I will give this beer another try and reevaluate my score at that time. The hops seemed to have lost all aroma and were flat out just bitter, as if the hops had been in the freezer for a while.

Thanks to Tim for the hookup while I was away!  Pours dark copper with a medium cream head and lots of lacing.  Great growler fill, carbonation level is perfect.  Aroma is toast and nutty malts covered with loads of fruity esters.  Flavor is big caramel and toasted malts upfront with very earthy clean hops and a light roast/burnt malt element in the finish.  Really nice beer!
Some caramel malts on nose.  Dark cloudy reddish brown.  Caramel malt and some spice but weird off metallic taste as well that was pretty objectionable.  Not good.
bottle.  The pour is copper, with a red hue.  The aroma is a nice roasted malt.  The taste has malt and caramel in it. pretty good and smooth.
Nice clear brown with a tan foam. Smoky aroma has hints of oak, toast, and nuts. Medium body spiked by the smoke and almond flavors. More biscuit and wood in the finish.
Brown pour with an off white head.  Aroma is sweet with some minor peat, and roastiness.  Taste has a decent hop character.  Nice finish.

Sample at Kinetic Brewing Company. Murky reddish-brown in color with a medium beige head that recedes slowly. Partial rings of lacing. Aroma of earthy malt, caramel and hops. Medium-bodied with flavors of caramel malt, hops and a touch of dark fruit. The finish is sweet malt up front and leaves a hoppy aftertaste. Decent overall.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a medium maroon brown with a small off white head which fades to very little lacing.  Aroma is of toasted sweet malts, caramel. some pine resin, some fruity hops, and some mild peaty smoke.  Taste is of  toasted sweet malts, piney hops, dark fruits, caramel, some toffee/bread pudding, and some smokey peat notes.  Has a medium body semi creamy mouthfeel and a semi dry, sweet but still somewhat bitter, medium finish.  overall, a good winter beer and excellent Scottish Ale.
Medium brown pour.  I like the sweet malts, a hint of peat, some roasted nuts.  Almost a hint of pine nuts.  Enough hops to offer good balance.  Good grain bill.  Enjoyable beer.
Poured light brown. No head. Aromas are of malt and light citrus hops. Mouthfeel is medium. Toasted malts and American hops are prominent. Firm bitterness. Good beer from a great brewery.

Bottle from Whole Foods, Arroyo (Pasadena). Brown color. Off white head. Aromas: toasted bread, a bit earthy, herbal. Even more toasted aromas retronasal: bread, chestnuts, also a hint of fruit. Flavor is toasted, medium sweet. Medium bodied. Finishes earthy bitter.

Its strange that the Scottish (not "Scotch") style hasnt really caught fire in the American craft beer scene. If done right, these beer have it all: plenty of malty sweetness balanced with hop bitterness and a hint of smoke. Theyre versatile as they work great as stand-alone beverages or accompaniment with a meal. Well, at least thats how Id describe Hangar 24 Hullabaloo Winter Beer. 

I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass.

Appearance: Dark, murky, cranberry/maroon colored body. Forms a large, off-white, frothy head which laces and retains really well.

Smell: Sweet, dark malts with a hint of dark fruit and a faint trace of smoke.

Taste: Ill admit I was rather hesitant going into Hangar 24 Hullabaloo Winter Beer, as Im not usually a fan of Scottish Ales. But one sip into it I knew this beer wasnt like most Ive experienced. Theres a much bigger taste profile here thats both robust, complex and perfectly balanced. It has that classic taste of bready, slightly fruity maltiness in the English style. Theres pronounced bitterness through the middle - a nice combination of astringency and piney, resiny hop character. The ending is the best part as theres a strong burst of caramel sweetness followed by semi-sweet chocolate and slight bitterness just before it fades away. Theres a smoky taste riding shotgun the entire time, but its nice and subtle and doesnt distract from the main palate. 

This is a really tasty palate, and a versatile one as I could see this beer working well in a variety of situational pairings: with a meal, with cheese, with dessert or as dessert. Take your pick.

Drinkability: Thankfully, Hangar 24 Hullabaloo Winter Beer drinks like a bigger beer than it actually is. You dont tend to get this much flavor out of 6.5% ABV. Its big enough that one serving satisfies, but light enough that it doesnt overwhelm you. Its smooth and soft all around with an almost creamy-like texture but distinct carbonation to give it some energy. The aftertaste is a little dry, but its easily tolerable.

Bottle.  Hazy brown pour with a slick of white foam.  Aroma is toasty nuts, roasted grain, light hop bitterness, and toffee.  Taste is light roast, nuts, perhaps some minimal peat, and some hop bitterness in the finish.  Watery mouthfeel.  Not bad.
Tap at the brewery. Clear deep amber pour. Beige foam. Nose is malty, raw, caramel, fairly neutral. Taste is soapy, dusty, dry, quite tannic. Papery finish. Eh. Spotty lace.

On tap at the source. Pours with a crystal clear bronze hued body with a medium sized off-white head. Aromas are malty, lightly earthy, toasty, medium caramel, and a bit of a distracting roast. Low ester. Flavors are quite roasty for the style, slightly watery, medium malt, toasted, caramel. Medium carbonation. Misses the mark a touch for me.

Aromas of molasses, wood and cream.   A very light off-white head on a crystal clear copper/amber body.   Although the appearance of this beer is clear and light, the body is substantial.  Light toffee and toasted/smoky wood flavors hit first followed by a creamy milk/bittersweet chocolate thats really interesting.   A well defined bitterness with earthy and grassy qualities keeps the sweetness in check and balances everything out nicely.  That bitterness hangs on through the end and leaves a dryness on the tongue along with the toasted/smoky, woody notes.   Really nice winter ale.

12oz bottle, no date from Olive Tree Market in OB for $1.89.  Clear copper brown with a half finger beige head, fading to a swirling creamy film before long. Clean toasty malt nose up front with nutty caramel, light herbal and earthy hops--seems wonderfully balanced so far. Flavor seemed to add a touch of woody hops, some yeast character. The caramel is still there, but again, minimal sweetness. Dry finish, bitterness peaked at a 2-3, earthy. Medium body with low carbonation. Quite tasty.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Aromas of oak and herbs. Deep copper in appearance. Flavors of smokey caramel, oak, herbs and oats. Subtle pines and hops on the finish. Overall, pretty basic ale with smokey characteristics. Id give this a C+ rating.

Truth in labeling.  This is a nice Scottish ale with an American hop presence.  But you get both flavors, not just one or the other.  A nice choice for a SoCal holiday season.  Some caramel notes blend into the bitterness nicely.

4 dec 2012, bottle. Light nut brown, clear, no bubbles. Nose is coffee and dark toast. Thin oct and fizzy. Lots if burnt malt and coffee in the finish. Crisp. Decent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Bine & Vine. Pours dark copper with a slight foamy yellow/beige head. Aroma is light roast malt with mild spice. Med body. Flavor has a hint of chocolate, then light caramel, mild roastiness, and enough bitterness to make it drinkable. Its flavorful, but far from imperially so. Good drinkin beer for the winter.

This review is from the bottle, upon initial pour the liquid is clear with an amber hue.  There is minimal head and the aroma is light and earthy with a malty sweet smell.  The taste is sweet with toffee notes and a hoppy finish.  Overall a good Scottish ale and a good beer for enjoying while its cold outside.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Copper colored pour with an off-white head. Nose of fruit, bread, and toasted malt. Slight nuttiness, a bit of yeast, very mild roast and chocolate. Some earthy and spicy hops, too. The flavor is mostly sweet bread and toffee malt. Some light hop bitterness, a bit of earth, spice, and roast. A mild chocolate flavor, some nuts, and a bit of water.
From a tap at the brewery, red brown in color, clear, above C02, frothy whote head, malty.Good stuff and would buy again.

1st rating. Bottle from total wine. Pours a super clear mahogany color with a tiny circular white head. Aroma is sweet and malty. Taste is slight roast and hazlenuts. Finishes dry and crisp. Nice winter brew.
